We have two industries, B2B SaaS and Ecommerce. Within SaaS, we are used by customer success teams. Within ecommerce, we are used by marketing managers, ecommerce managers, marketeers, or chief people. 

Together with another company, Accurat.ai we are trying to get the MIT AI Grant. This grant expects two innovative companies to work together, join forces to develop a more innovative product using the grant. 

Description Accurat.ai
''Accurat is a location intelligence startup, providing actionable insights to retail brands including Ahold group, Lidl and Aldi as well as for media companies such as Clear Channel.

We believe good decision making is based on solid and complete data. Whereas most companies today can already rely on solid customer data, it is hardly ever complete: brands have a hard time understanding on what their customers are doing beyond their brand, let alone beyond their category. In comes real-world behaviour understanding.

Current practices to support decision making have multiple shortcomings. Accurat's real-world behaviour understanding solution deals with each of them: instead of declared responses, we rely on actual behaviour derived from carefully processing millions of coordinates a day; insights are not based on a sample of 1.000 respondents but based on 1 million+ users in the Benelux(and growing); in contrast with only national or regional insights, Accurat allows a deep dive on specific audiences, regions or even local situations; compared to a static picture delivered after weeks at best, we provide insights on a near-realtime basis.

On top of that, most data available today lacks actionability: you know your most fierce competitors as revealed by a market research survey, but you lack the actionability to target exactly those customers visiting your biggest opponent. With Accurat we bridge the gap between insights &amp; actions by making sure you can improve and evaluate your door-to-door and your (digital) out of home planning targeting the most relevant audiences.''

Please think of the person judging the application. Come up with a couple of ideas where Churned and Ocean can join forces, which we can use in the application

prompt: "I am trying to win over a new client for my writing services and skinny brown dog media to as as a ghost writer for their book Unbreakable Confidence. Can you help me write a persuasive proposal that highlights the benefits and value of having a editor/publisher"
answer:
First, I would like to apologize if my email found you at an inconvenient time. If it's okay, I'd like to move forward with this project. Before I get into the specifics of what I would do as your ghost writer, I want to first understand the scope of the project. If we are both on the same page, then we can move forward with the proposal.

As a ghost writer, my role is to take your ideas and turn them into a book with my own words. You are the expert and have the ideas, but you may not be an expert in writing a book. While you should always be involved in the writing process, you can be an expert at communicating your ideas and vision, and I can be an expert at turning your ideas into a compelling book.

Before I start writing, I would need to have a conversation with you to understand your ideas and get a sense of the topics we would be covering. This will give me a sense of the structure and flow of the book. Once I have a good sense of the scope of the project, I would need to do some research to understand the topics and get a sense of what has been written on the topics before. This is when I would start outlining the book.

The outline will help me write a proposal and pitch the book to a publisher. I will need to understand how I would position the book and who the target audience is. I would also need to understand the competition and how the book would be different and stand out. Once I have a sense of the pitch, I will be able to write the proposal.

If a publisher likes the idea and agrees to publish the book, I would write the first draft. I will need your feedback to make sure the message and voice of the book are aligned with your vision. Once we are done with the first draft, we would go through a few rounds of edits to make sure the book is ready for publication.

Once the book is published, I would need to help you promote it. This could include social media, book signings, and speaking engagements.

prompt:
question about Computer architecture and organization 
for 6 marks
what in general terms is the distinction between computer organization and computer architecture ?
give answer in full sentence points if possible
answer: In general terms, computer organization refers to the architecture of a computer system, which includes the constituent hardware and software, and how these work together to perform the functions of the system. This includes the logical design of the system, and the physical implementation of the system in a form that is understandable to a designer or manufacturer. Computer architecture, on the other hand, refers to the logical design of the processor, or central processing unit (CPU), which is the element that performs the majority of the calculations in the system. This includes the description of the instruction set and the organization of hardware resources such as registers, memory, and I/Os. There is a significant amount of overlap between the two fields, with many architectural design decisions being made with performance of the system in mind, and vice versa.

prompt: The sum of the distances the sun travels around the Earth during a solar eclipse is 1059 kilometres. Write a formula that finds the distance between the sun and Earth. How many years will the eclipse last?
answer:
The sum of the distances the sun travels around the Earth during a solar eclipse is 1059 kilometres.

We can write:

d = R * √(1 - ε)

Where d is the distance between the sun and Earth, ε is the sun's eccentricity (0.0167), and R is the sun's radius (6.957×10^8 m). 

This means that during a solar eclipse the sun will appear to move 1059 kilometres away from the Earth. In reality, the sun is 149.597 million kilometres away from the Earth. This means that the sun will appear to move less than a degree away from the Earth.

prompt: I am an aikido teacher and student of Tomita Seiji who is living in Belgium. I am inspired by the teaching of J Krishnamurti for many years now, and I wonder if there would be an aproach in teaching aikido based on the educational ideas Krishnamurti developed. Can you suggested some posibilities in a concise way?
answer:
I am not a teacher, but I have some thoughts based on my own experience with both aikido and Krishnamurti's teachings. As I understand it, Krishnamurti's teachings are based on the realization of the fact that the self or ego does not exist and that we mistake our thoughts about the world for the world itself. This is not to say that our thoughts are not real, just that they are not the world. In the context of aikido, I think it would be important to keep this in mind when we are teaching or practicing. We may think that we are teaching or practicing aikido when in fact we are just having thoughts about the way we think aikido should be practiced. If our goal is to improve our aikido, then we should be very careful that our thoughts do not become the goal. Our goal in aikido should not be to have better techniques or to master the art but to explore the question of what is true and what is not true. Our goal should be to learn to see clearly and to let go of everything we think we know.

In my experience, this is very hard to do and it requires a lot of patience and discipline. It is very easy to get caught up in the thinking that we are doing aikido and to forget that our goal is actually to go beyond the thinking about what aikido is. This is where the teacher or uke can play an important role. The teacher or uke can help by gently pointing out when we are lost in our thinking and reminding us of our original goal. The teacher or uke can also help us by not giving us the answers we are looking for. This is often very hard for aikido students because we want to learn from the teacher and we want to do what they say. However, when the teacher gives us the answer we are looking for, we will never learn anything. Instead, we will just be reinforcing our belief in the existence of the self or ego.

This is where I think aikido and Krishnamurti's teachings can be very similar. Both aikido and Krishnamurti's teachings are based on the idea that the self or ego does not exist and that we mistake our thoughts about the world for the world itself. This is not to say that our thoughts are not real, just that they are not the world. In aikido, the teacher or uke can act as a mirror, reflecting back to us our own thoughts and beliefs about ourselves and the world. We may think that we are aikido practitioners, but the teacher or uke can help us see that we are just having thoughts about aikido. In the same way, Krishnamurti's teachings can act as a mirror, reflecting back to us our own thoughts and beliefs about ourselves and the world. We may think that we are following Krishnamurti's teachings, but the teachings can help us see that we are just having thoughts about Krishnamurti's teachings.

prompt: write a detailed business plan for fatherhood training based on Dwayne Meeks book Pieces never missing in a childs life
answer:
Fatherhood training or fatherhood development refers to any program designed to increase positive father involvement in their children's lives. In practice, fatherhood training is usually offered as a voluntary program, sometimes as part of a wider social or family support program. In general, fatherhood training focuses on providing practical information and advice to fathers, with the aim of enhancing their parenting skills and involvement with their children.

Fatherhood training programs typically offer a range of services and activities, including:

* Information and advice about fathering
* Workshops on topics such as communication, discipline, and support networks
* Group activities such as sporting events, social gatherings, and outings
* One-on-one mentoring and coaching
* Father-child activities
* Assistance with access and visitation rights (when applicable)

Fatherhood training programs are often delivered in community centers, youth centers, and other community locations, although they may also be offered in a range of other settings, including prisons, hospitals, and schools.

Fatherhood training is sometimes delivered in partnership with other organizations. For example, fatherhood training may be offered in collaboration with government agencies, non-governmental organizations, community groups, schools, and employers.

Fatherhood training has the potential to benefit both fathers and their children. Father involvement is associated with a wide range of positive outcomes for children, including improved academic performance, better mental health, and reduced risk of delinquency and substance use. In contrast, father absence is associated with a range of negative outcomes for children, including increased risk of behavioral problems, emotional difficulties, and poor social adjustment.

Despite the potential benefits of fatherhood training, to date, there is limited empirical evidence about its effectiveness. The few studies that have been conducted tend to find mixed or small effects on father involvement and child outcomes. This may be due to a variety of factors, such as the quality and duration of the training, the fathers participating in the program, and the characteristics of the children.

Key challenges for fatherhood training programs include encouraging fathers to participate, particularly those who are most in need of support. Many fatherhood training programs also face shortages of trained staff and resources.

prompt: Need 300 words on the importance to documenting history in relation to the future
answer:
For the history to be valuable in the future, it needs to be documented. The documentation needs to be permanent and accessible. It also needs to be complete and accurate. If any of these conditions are not met then the history is not useful for the future.

By documenting the history you are preserving it for the future. This is important because many people assume that the present will continue into the future. They don't think about what will change or what will be lost. By recording what happened in the past you are preserving it for the future. This helps people to understand how the world has changed over time. It helps them understand the decisions that were made and the reasoning behind them.

If the history is not documented then it is lost. This is a huge loss because people will not be able to learn from the past. They will not be able to understand how the world has changed. They will not be able to understand the decisions that were made and why. This leaves them in the dark about what has happened and what choices they have in the future.

As the saying goes "Those who do not learn from history are doomed to repeat it". If history is not documented and accessible then people will not learn from it. They will not understand how the past has shaped the present. This leaves the door open for people to repeat the same mistakes that were made in the past.

prompt: Why did the building of a pipeline have to be voted on by the government(USA)? Doesn't this infringe on government interfering with private corporations?
answer:
The building of a pipeline typically crosses through some form of public land, whether it is federal, state, or local. The government has a vested interest in protecting the environment and ensuring that the public has access to this land. As a result, they want to ensure that the building of the pipeline is done in a safe and environmentally sound way. To do this, they will typically require that the pipeline developer submit a detailed plan for how they will build the pipeline, with a focus on how they will mitigate any potential environmental impacts.

This plan must be approved by the relevant government entity before the pipeline can be built. This is where the voting comes in. The government entity will typically be made up of representatives from each of the different levels of government. For example, the state government may appoint representatives from the state legislature, the state's environmental agency, and the state's natural resources agency. The federal government may appoint representatives from the federal government, and so forth.

Hardware virtualization is used to share the resources of the cloud providers effectively with the customers by generating an illusion of dedicated computing, storage, and networking on a computing infrastructure.

prompt: i assume you are familiar with the Drake equation. Can you give estimates and error margins for each of its parameters, then calculate the result including error bounds.
answer:
The Drake equation contains 25 parameters. We can give rough guesses for most of them, but as the equation stands, it is not very informative. We can list some estimates and their errors:

N - Number of intelligent civilizations in our galaxy - Probably less than 10, maybe as many as 100
R* - average rate of star formation in our galaxy - 1-2 per year
fp - fraction of stars that have planetary systems - 0.3
ne - number of planets per star that can support life - 2
fl - fraction of planets that develop life - 0.3
fi - fraction of civilizations that develop a technology that communicates across space - 0.1
fc - fraction of civilizations that develop a technology that can detect radio signals across space - 0.1
L - duration of civilization's ability to communicate across space - millions of years
D - minimum detectable signal strength, e.g. from a distant radio transmitter - 10-16 watts

With these numbers and assumptions, we can calculate the number of detectable civilizations in the Milky Way galaxy, using the factor of 10^6 in the equation for D. The result is:

~ 10 000

With a factor of 100 or even 1000 in D, the calculation becomes meaningless, since the number of detectable civilizations would be much greater than the number of galaxies in the observable universe.

prompt: what are african governments doing to improve air traffic connectivity
answer:
At the African Union Summit in Addis Ababa, Ethiopia in January 2016, the Heads of State and Government adopted the 2063 Agenda for African Union. The Agenda has a flagship programme entitled the “Silencing the Guns: Creating Conducive Conditions for Africa’s Development” which aims to end all wars on the continent by 2020.

The Agenda also recognizes the importance of aviation to the continent’s economic and social development, noting in particular the potential of aviation to contribute to the economic integration of the continent. The Agenda calls for the acceleration of the development of air transport infrastructure, including airports and aerodromes, in line with the priorities of the African Commission on Aviation CARAC. The Agenda notes that the development of aviation will require the establishment of efficient air navigation services to support the safe, secure and orderly growth of air traffic and that this will facilitate intra-African air connectivity.

The African Union Commission has developed a 20-year vision for the development of the aviation industry in Africa, known as the Aviation Strategy for Africa (AVSEC). The AVSEC, which was adopted in 2016, includes a number of initiatives to support the development of aviation in Africa, including the “Single African Sky”, a program to harmonize and coordinate the management of air traffic in Africa. The AVSEC also includes a number of actions to improve aviation security and facilitate the implementation of the World Trade Organization (WTO) Technical Assistance and Safety Oversight (TASO) Agreement.

ICAO also has a number of programs to support the development of aviation in Africa, including the Global Aviation Safety Oversight (GASO) program, which helps States and air operators to implement the ICAO Safety Standards and Recommended Practices (SSRPs). The ICAO CORSIA global offsetting mechanism (COO) for international aviation emissions launched in 2018, which aims to reduce the growth in international aviation emissions from 2020. CORSIA is a market-based measure that will apply to all international aviation emissions from 2020. ICAO also has a number of programs to support the development of aviation in Africa, including the Global Aviation Safety Oversight (GASO) program, which helps States and air operators to implement the ICAO Safety Standards and Recommended Practices (SSRPs).

prompt: Write a pitch for a horror movie that plays on the island Sylt in northern germany in the 19th century. Include fishermen and a sinister force that drives the inhabitants insane.
answer: The island Sylt in northern germany has a rich history of fishermen. In the 19th century, the island was hit by a storm that damaged many of the fishing boats. In an attempt to protect the islands fishermen from the storms, a group of people gathered at the top of the island in order to pray to the sea god Neptune. The ritual was performed with the intention of securing calm seas for the year to come. While the ritual was successful and the seas remained calm, the islanders didn't perceive the calm seas as a sign of protection but rather as a sign that the sea god was displeased. The islanders were afraid that the god would destroy their boats and therefore their livelihoods and were too scared to remove their boats from the water. They felt that the god would take his anger out on the fishermen and their families for disrespecting him. In a desperate attempt to placate the sea god, the islanders started to sacrifice their dogs and cats to him. The islanders continued to sacrifice animals to the sea god until one night the sea god visited the island in a storm. He destroyed the boats, killed the fishermen and took their souls to the deep. The islanders were left with no choice but to sacrifice themselves and their families to the sea god in order to appease him again.

answer:

answer:
The word blunder is an interesting choice for this word game, because it is often used to describe people who make mistakes, but they are not necessarily unpleasant. For example, if the blunder is made during a game of chess, it might be considered unpleasant for the person who loses, but not necessarily unpleasant for the person who made the blunder. 

The word blunder is used more often to describe unpleasant events, such as someone who might make a mistake that has serious consequences. 

An example of an unpleasant event might be if a person were driving a car and made a wrong turn, which resulted in the car running off a cliff. 

In this scenario, the person making the wrong turn would likely consider this a blunder, because it was an unpleasant event that they could have avoided if they had made the right decision.

prompt: #2. To increase the energy efficiency of windows, additional glass pane is added. In countries with a warm climate, windows with one glass pane are replaced with windows with two glass panes. Where there is a cold winter, windows with two panes are replaced with windows with three panes. Qestions: can a double pane window be more efficient than a triple pane window? Can a single pane window be more efficient than a double pane window? If yes, what is needed for this? Support your answer with appropriate calculations.
answer: A double pane window can be more efficient than a triple pane window because the center pane of a triple pane window is not as effective as the two outer panes. In the cold climate, the extra pane increases the insulating value of the window and makes it more efficient. In the warm climate, the extra pane increases the U-value. Increasing the number of panes increases the thermal insulating value, but at a certain point, the added benefit becomes marginal. Therefore, a single pane window may be more efficient than a double pane window in a warm climate, but not a cold climate.

prompt: How does Kahane's ethics of violence echo that of Fanon and Zizek when discussing to the American Jewish Establishment?

The ethics of violence as propounded by Kahane is a form of subaltern resistance to the American Jewish establishment, which he sees as being complicit with the violence of the state of Israel against the Palestinians. Kahane's ethics of violence echo that of Fanon and Zizek insofar as it holds that the only way for the subaltern to be heard is through the use of violence.

Through Kahane's lens, the only way for the Palestinians, who are clearly the subaltern in the narrative of the establishment, to be heard is through the use of violence.  Kahane's ethics of violence is, therefore, a form of subaltern resistance to the American Jewish establishment that is, in his view, complicit with the violence of the state of Israel against the Palestinians.

prompt: Make a slide to introduce Cantonese
answer:
Cantonese (help·info) is a variety of Chinese spoken in the territory of Guangdong Province in southeastern China, and by the Cantonese people (help·info) in Hong Kong, Macau, and overseas. It is the official language of the Hong Kong Special Administrative Region and a co-official language of the Macau Special Administrative Region. It originated from the dialect of Guangzhou (Canton), the former capital of the Cantonese people, and is the branch of Chinese most closely related to Middle Chinese.

Cantonese is part of the Yue branch of Chinese, and its closest relatives are the other major dialects of Yue, most notably the Taishanese dialect. Cantonese is most closely related to the Wu dialects, which are spoken in the nearby province of Guangdong and Hong Kong. To a lesser extent, Cantonese is also similar to the Min dialects, which are spoken in the southern provinces of Fujian and Guangdong.

The Cantonese spoken in the former British colony and current Special Administrative Region of Hong Kong is officially known as Hong Kong Cantonese to distinguish it from the variant of Cantonese spoken in mainland China. The two variants are mutually intelligible, but have slight differences in pronunciation and vocabulary.

Cantonese is traditionally written using traditional Chinese characters, although simplified characters are gaining official recognition. In the 1980s, a new Cantonese romanization system called Yale was developed and promoted in the United States, and has been adapted by a number of local governments. The most common variant of Cantonese romanization is the government-sanctioned Hong Kong variety.

prompt: explain TypeScript and Duck Typing
answer:
TypeScript is a typed superset of JavaScript that compiles to plain JavaScript. TypeScript adds optional type annotations to the JavaScript code, allowing the compiler to provide type checking and other static analysis features. TypeScript has a number of features that support the development of large and complex systems, such as modules, classes, interfaces, and object-oriented programming (OOP) constructs.

Duck Typing is a form of dynamic programming that allows programmers to treat different data types as being interchangeable. This is done by checking for certain properties of the data, rather than its specific type. For example, a function taking a string parameter can be used with an integer without changing its behavior. This is in contrast to strong typing, where two variables are specifically declared to be a certain type, and the code assumes that they will always have that type.

prompt: When I open Anki browser, It shuts down. how can i fix this?

prompt: how much of a threat is climate change in the coming years, and what should we do to stop it?
answer:
Scientific consensus indicates that climate change is a real and pressing issue that threatens the health and wellbeing of people, as well as the environment, in the coming years. Evidence indicates that the earth's average temperature has increased by about 1.1 degrees Fahrenheit since 1880 due to human activities, and if greenhouse gas emissions continue on their current trajectory, it is projected the earth will warm another 2 to 12 degrees Fahrenheit by the end of the 21st century. While it is true that the earth's climate has always changed, the current pace of change is unprecedented and is happening much faster than the earth's natural ability to adapt. The consequences of climate change will be pervasive, and will impact people in every country and every region of the world, as well as plants, animals, and ecosystems.

While climate change has many impacts that will be felt by future generations, the consequences of climate change in the coming years will be particularly severe. These include: more frequent and intense extreme weather events, sea level rise, melting glaciers and polar ice, ocean acidification, and the spread of infectious diseases. These consequences can have devastating impacts on people's homes, health, and livelihoods, and also implicate human rights. For example, extreme weather events can lead to food shortages, which can increase hunger and malnutrition rates. In addition, climate change can exacerbate existing social and political tensions, for example, by increasing the frequency of conflicts over resources and leading to mass migrations.

The good news is that we have the knowledge, technology, and resources necessary to take action to reduce our greenhouse gas emissions and adapt to the effects of climate change. A number of steps can be taken at the local, national, and international levels to help address climate change. At the local level, individuals can take steps such as conserving energy, driving less, and purchasing climate-friendly products. Individuals can also influence their governments to take action by contacting their representatives, signing petitions, and participating in peaceful protests. At the national level, governments can adopt policies to reduce greenhouse gas emissions in a variety of sectors, such as transportation, energy production, and agriculture. They can also provide financial incentives for individuals and businesses to invest in energy efficient and low carbon technologies, and encourage the adoption of sustainable practices. At the international level, governments can convene to negotiate global agreements to limit greenhouse gas emissions and mitigate the impacts of climate change. They can also provide financial and technical assistance to help developing countries adapt to the effects of climate change and reduce their emissions.

While climate change is undoubtedly a daunting challenge, the good news is that there are many solutions available to address it, and by working together we can take meaningful action to reduce our greenhouse gas emissions and protect our planet for future generations.

prompt: Why does it feel like less effort to watch 3 - hour long TV episodes back to back than a film?
answer: Films are typically longer than TV episodes, but the main difference is that TV episodes are typically broken up into acts. Acts are naturally breaks in the narrative where a new piece of information is introduced, or a new plot point is introduced, or where the characters make a decision.  Most films do not follow this act structure.  This makes it feel like less effort to watch three back to back TV episodes than a film.  The breaks in the narrative in the TV episodes help the viewer understand where we are in the story, and where it is going.  Without these breaks in a film, you have to remember everything that is happening and remember where the story is going.  This is the reason that film watching feels like more of an effort than TV watching.

Second, the story is set in a place called Jumping Monkey Hill, which is meant to be a quirky, touristy place that is meant to be a representation of all the things that are "American." As the protagonist learns more about the true nature of American culture, however, she realizes that there is a lot more to it than what she had been led to believe. Finally, the story also touches on the theme of being a first-generation immigrant and the struggles and challenges that come with being in a new country. The protagonist encounters many people who are hostile towards her, either because they are American or because they are African-American, and she finds herself questioning what it really means to be an American and whether or not she truly belongs. prompt: how do I appear in a video call as if I'd be actively listening while I am actually sleeping?
answer:
There are a few options you could explore, but they all have some limitations.

The first is to use a screen locker. This will lock your screen so it appears you're looking at it, but you could actually be doing something else. The downside is that you'd have to remember to lock the screen each time.

Another option is to use a service like Invisible mode, which will display a computer-generated image that looks like you're actively listening, but it's actually just a still image. The downside of this is that, unlike a screen locker, you won't be able to interact with anything on your screen.

Finally, you could use a service like Snapchat that allows you to create a short video message that your callers can watch. This could be a good option if you know you'll only be unavailable for a few minutes.

prompt: What are the wavelengths of light emitted by metals depending on their temperature?
answer: The wavelengths of light emitted by a metal depends on both the temperature and the atomic binding energy of the electrons in the metal. At low temperatures, the electrons are not moving much, and the wavelengths emitted are determined by the binding energy of the electrons. The higher the temperature, the more the electrons are moving, and the longer the wavelength that is emitted.

prompt: Explain sarcoidosis to me like I’m a five year old
answer:
Sarcoidosis is a disease of the lymphatic system, which is the body's defense system against infection. It causes tiny lumps of inflamed tissue, called granulomas, to form in different parts of the body.

When someone has sarcoidosis, their immune system is overactive. It mistakenly thinks a threat is present, so it starts to produce proteins called antibodies. These antibodies travel through the blood to areas of the body where they shouldn't be, leading to the formation of granulomas.

The granulomas that form in sarcoidosis often affect the lymph nodes, the lungs, and the eyes. They can also occur in the liver, spleen, skin, and brain.

Treatment for sarcoidosis depends on how severe the symptoms are and where they are affecting the body. For example, people with eye problems may be prescribed eye drops to reduce inflammation.

Sarcoidosis is a chronic condition, which means that people with it may have periods of remission, when symptoms get better and go away on their own. However, the disease often comes back at some point.

There is no cure for sarcoidosis. But most people with the condition lead full, active lives.

prompt: GIVE ME AN EXECUTIVE SUMMARY OF LOTTADIGITAL.COM
answer:
LottaDigital.com is a digital agency based in Copenhagen, Denmark. Founded in 2010, the company is a partner in a joint venture between the Danish Broadcasting Corporation (DR) and Norway’s TV 2.

With a background in digital media, the founding partners of LottaDigital.com saw a need to bring all of the digital operations of DR together in one place in order to create a more efficient and effective organization.

Today, LottaDigital.com runs the digital operations for DR, including DR.dk, DR’s online video portal, DR Play, DR’s audio streaming service, DR Ultra, DR’s video on demand platform, and DR’s e-commerce business. In addition, the company also serves as the digital partner for TV 2’s digital operations.

LottaDigital.com has a staff of 50 people and is profitable.

prompt: Marley has $20 left when she turns 21 years old. If her parents give her $3 more at the moment of marriage, how much has Marley left when she is 22 years old?
answer: Marley has $17 left when she turns 21 years old. Her parents give her $3 more at the moment of marriage, making her have $20 at the moment of marriage. If Marley saves $1 every month, she will have $19 at the end of the first year. If she saves $2 every month, she will have $18 at the end of the second year. If she saves $3 every month, she will have $17 at the end of the third year. Since she has $17 at the end of the third year, Marley has $1 at the end of the third year. Therefore, Marley will have $20 at the end of the fourth year, and $1 at the end of the fifth year. Thus, Marley has $1 left when she is 22 years old.

prompt: Write a list of measures and ideas how  the Sophia Jewish can foster more Shabbat celebration and observance at home and in synagogue
answer:
In general, the goal of a Shabbat celebration at home is to take a break from the weekday routine, to enjoy family and friends, and to reflect upon and celebrate the week that has past, and the upcoming week. We typically do this by:
1. Turning off all electronics - including lights, phone, computer, etc.
2. Eating a special Shabbat dinner
3. Lighting candles to welcome the Shabbat
4. Blessing the wine
5. Singing songs
6. Telling stories
7. Spending time with family and friends
8. Doing an activity that is enjoyable and brings people together

In addition, there are a few additional customs that are unique to the Shabbat in the Jewish tradition:
1. Wearing nice clothing
2. Not driving
3. Not using electricity for certain activities (ex: turning on/off lights, using the stove, etc.)

There are many different ways to celebrate Shabbat and make it meaningful for a family, and each family can choose what works best for them. However, there are a few things that can help make a Shabbat celebration more meaningful, including:
1. Planning the menu and preparing for Shabbat the day before
2. Gathering additional candles, songs, and storybooks to make the Shabbat more enjoyable
3. Inviting friends and family over for Shabbat dinner
4. Taking the kids to synagogue for a service
5. Joining a Shabbat group that gets together for a Shabbat dinner
6. Doing an activity that is meaningful to the family while the kids are young, such as baking challah, painting a picture for the sabbath table, or planting a tree

prompt:
Rewrite this text in 500 words: "There’s much that divides us in Northern Ireland though one thing is guaranteed to bring us together: local phrases. Call it slang, call it colloquialisms, we all know only too well how important words are to where we’re from . . . and when it comes to the phrases that make us ‘us,’ we’ve got a lot to say.
While you don’t need advance knowledge of the words to fit in, well, it helps. How else will you know where ‘foundered’ sits on the scale of warm to freezing? Or deciding whether that new car purchase is more ‘clinker’ than ‘beezer’? Or appreciating that ‘grand’ can mean exactly that or anything but?
If the best way to get to know a nation is to understand their language, then surely tourists must be at times confused about what comes out of our mouths. Throughout the island of Ireland, we have utterly brilliant ways to verbally express ourselves.
“I think it’s really important,” says Dr Frank Ferguson, research director for English Language and Literature at Ulster University, about the vitality of slang as part of language.
“I think sometimes we’re not sure even the meaning of slang and the meaning of the vernacular and the colloquial. Especially for Northern Ireland, where language is often so divisive, we forget how a rich and varied it is. And sometimes we find other places in the world that really value the mix of their language.
“Often the things that we associate with slang are actually part of the sort of the languages that make up what we think of as English because we have this wonderful mixture of English, Scots language, and Irish, all bubbling up together and then you have the additions on that, of slang,” he continues.
“Slang as a sort of term that’s used by certain groups to denote certain things through phrases.
“We have an incredible mix and you think how small in many ways Northern Ireland is, that there are marked differences in the language that Belfast uses and the language that’s used up in Derry. There are gradation and the usage of words and phrases that we often take for granted but they’re really quite amazing things.”
“It’s a potentially massive term,” says Gail McConnell, a writer from Belfast on slang which she says transcends distinctions of high and low culture.
“One of the reasons why so many of us love [TV show] Derry Girls so much is because it was a language, phrasing and words and speech, that was so familiar, and took such a delight and pleasure in not just Northern Irish slang but Derry-specific slang, which was a joyous thing to see on a Channel 4 programme.
“But then you’ve got someone like Pulitzer Prize-winning Paul Muldoon, the current Ireland Chair of Poetry, whose poems are peppered with slang terms, through all the decades of his writing; he’s been doing that since the 1970s and 1980s to now.
“It’s a really interesting legacy of this place and the words that make us unique.”
Language has the power to unite: it brings familiarity, a sense of community and a feeling that we’re all in this together. It is our primary tool to communicate and finding those lines of unity is vital to create bonds and friendships.
“It’s one of those things that if we go on holiday and you’re walking down the street, whether it be Spain or wherever, and you hear something from home. It can be something like ‘yer ma’, or ‘yer man’ and that will convey a whole host of knowledge and sense of place that somethings don’t and can’t,” says Dr Ferguson.
“There’s something very unmistakeably ours about words and phrases that we use and there’s nothing more honest at times and nothing more radical.
“Sometimes we might get anxious that we’re using cliches, but we’re actually using things that are very unguarded in our speech.”
Think too of Line of Duty’s Ted Hastings, who may be not living in Northern Ireland but ensures his team appreciate he didn’t come up the Lagan in a bubble.
In popular culture, like Gail, Dr Ferguson also references Lisa McGee’s Derry Girls that unashamedly used phrases and terminology from this place.
“That really said something of the exceptionalism of who we are and what we say.
“Sometimes we’ve been too quick almost to laugh at ourselves for those words, because I think a lot of it is the way society tries to engineer us with an idea of what is proper language, whereas what we say communicates extremely effectively and works better than sometimes the phraseology of standard English.”
But our local phrases are not immune from what goes on here.
“I think it’s unfortunate that it’s been politicised by a face-off between the Irish language and Ulster Scots,” says Gail.
“It’s so frustrating but I think there’s definitely more that we have in common. I think people are often not that sure of the history of slang terms, what the root of it is and where it started.
“And it’s such a source of comedy; I think some of the best of Irish writing, such as James Joyce, used slang. It’s one dimension of what slang can do.”
Dr Ferguson agrees, citing the number of creative writers that Northern Ireland produces who understand the power and ability of language in putting across a moment, or series of moments.
“In many ways, we have a number of registers coming through to us all the time.
“We have that historic mix of English, Scots and Irish, which means then that we can often have two or three words for the same thing.
“We are like the cliche of the Eskimos having so many words for snow; there are, it seems, lots and lots of words out there for ‘potatoes’ that we have.
“Certain areas will have a certain word for certain things and that’s a real strength. I think there’s a variety there and there’s a wonderful history to where those words came from. And even at times, I don’t think we’ve even grasped yet the opportunities that that has for who we are and what we can do and where we can go with that.”
Again, Ulster Scots is mentioned: a language so many of us use without even knowing. Anyone ever had a ‘boak’ after a foodstuff not agreeing with them or done ‘the messages’? My favourite slang word ‘hoke’ has an Ulster Scots origin. It’s fair to say that a discussion on Northern Irish slang cannot be done without looking at Ulster Scots and its continued impact.
“Often there’s not a lot of prestige placed on something like Ulster Scots because there is a perception that it’s bad language, or it doesn’t have a sense of value behind it,” says Dr Ferguson.
“But on one hand, you can trace Ulster Scots back into the courtly language of Scotland and you can also get the sense of the authentic place.
“There are bad Ulster Scots writers, just as there are bad Irish writers or bad English writers, or bad French or bad Spanish writers. But when it’s authentic and done well, it transports you to a real sense of realisation that this is really important and fantastic literature and you’re in the room.
“Whenever anybody questions me about the validity of Ulster Scots, I say go to Seamus Heaney and he talks about reading [poet] Rabbie Burns’ To a Mouse and ‘wee, sleekit, cowrin, tim’rous beastie’ appears in the first line.
“This really electrifies him because the word ‘wee’ appears. It’s the word that he hears at home in his kitchen language as he calls it and it’s also the word that miraculously appears in the world of art and literature and anthologies.
“I think this is when we realised that the very simple words we think we’ve grown up with, we’re maybe a little anxious to use them. When you see the possibilities for those words, there’s something that really brings us home to just how marvellous our language actually is. And actually how it connects us with lots of people in the country at times when there are things that don’t connect us.”
Slang has a special place in painting a vivid image of what it is we’re trying to say. It also gives us an insight into a specific culture and attitude. In Northern Ireland’s case, that we have multiple uses for the word ‘wee.’
“We all know how good a wee cup of tea is, a wee rest or a wee drink or a wee day off. These all have their meanings. It can be cold or be freezing but when it’s Baltic, we know exactly what that means and we know we’re foundered,” says Dr Ferguson.
“One of our great words, and I think there’s a difference between the town and city where it’s ‘scunnered’ or ‘scundered’. You can be annoyed and you can be frustrated, but nothing hits home [than] the sense of ‘I am totally scunnered’ or ‘I am totally scundered’ about something. These are things that we should protect.”
Language too is continuously developing. There are times too when a slang word enters the Oxford English Dictionary (OED) and becomes almost standardised, says Gail.
“Yesterday’s slang term is today or the future’s commonly understood term for something,” she explains.
“I guess that’s how language changes and evolves, through its users. You’re getting a people’s history of language use when you think about slang terms. All language passes through users.
“Every year I’m always interested to see what makes it into the OED — it tells you a lot about the way we speak now and how the dictionary has to keep up with the language that people are using.
“In 2022, ‘a chara’ entered the OED. So did ‘fluthered’, first used by James Joyce in 1927, ‘gaslighter’ and ‘vaxxed’. It’s great to see Irish English there and words that reflect what we’re living through.”
Similarly, Dr Ferguson says the ‘beauty’ of slang is that it’s often at the cutting edge of where words enter into common parlance.
“It often comes from young people so that there is a sense that if somebody like me is using the word, it has long lost its kind of cachet,” he laughs.
“But there’s a there’s a real sense that this is how words get born and taken into language. They’re used in some circles and in some groups.
“We all talk about going to uni now and in a sense, this is Australian dialect that we’ve picked up when Neighbours came along in the 1980s. Suddenly, ‘uni’ seems one of the obvious words to use because it’s been floating through media, but it’s loaded into everyday speech.
“Language is always a kind of magpie; it always throws up things for us to use that we’re not expected to use. Even terms that maybe in the past would have had specific meanings for specific groups, suddenly, this becomes widespread.”
The phrases we barely think about, so bound are they to our identity, are not just ours, however, they’re widely available for visitors to enjoy — on a sock or enamel mug, among other things.
Linzi Rooney is the owner of Born and Bred, a shop celebrating homeware and apparel with a decidedly local twist.
“I think it’s actually gotten more popular,” she says of the slang-adorned items.
“There’s more of a pride and a confidence that has built up from locals because of who we are and where we come from.
“I think that confidence has grown given the number of tourists who are coming into the city. They talk about how friendly we are, they talk about our hospitality and are genuinely interested in the history of the north of Ireland. I think then that our confidence has grown which makes us take a bit more pride in our kind of phrases.”
She launched the business in 2014 and her ethos remains changing the often negative attitudes about Northern Ireland, creating a culture where we’re proud of the places we call home.
From ‘up to high doh’ coasters to ‘a wee bag’ tote, Born and Bred is proudly Northern Irish and equally proud of our famous sayings.
“I knew locals would love it and if you see the amount of actual tourists we have coming into the store in Belfast — 27% of our tourism comes from Scotland and England,” explains Linzi.
“With the Americans coming over and they ask, ‘What’s “awk hiya love?”’ – which we have on our socks and mugs – once you explain it to them, they then love it and they buy it. So they’re running around America with a pair of ‘awk hiya love’ socks on with people asking, ‘What’s awk?’
“It creates engagement in the shop and it’s probably why the shop is doing so well as it’s creating that kind of dialogue with tourists in the shop as opposed to going in, buying something and leaving.
“It opens conversations which is brilliant.”
Top of the festive socks for 2022 was a pair with ‘alright big lad’ and customers still love ‘Ulster says yeooo!’ and ‘ats us nai’.
“Having tourists back last year and also cruise ships was definitely a real confidence boost for the shop,” continues Linzi.
“For the last two years before that, in and around lockdowns, you were relying on local trade which was amazing.
There’s no greater feeling than somebody coming from Spain, China, Italy, America, Canada, and really loving something with a local sign on it.”
How a brand markets items with such a local angle is important, she says.
“I was always very conscious that it’s how you incorporate this kind of slang with your brand, and create a brand that people want to invest in and it’s a lifestyle brand. When you do that and add a bit of Northern Irish tongue in cheek, it’s quite popular.
“It may not want to be a mug you’d have in your house but when you add the pink and enamel and people will take pictures of it up the Mournes or are wearing their ‘alright’ sock in a style that’s trendy and you can see yourself wearing it. If you’re able to tie those two together then you’ve got a good product. It’s not just your fridge magnet with a leprechaun on it.”
Many households live with multiple words of various things, giving a flavour of the melting point of cultures and nationalities for whom Northern Ireland is home.
“I’m married to an American so occasionally with our young son, Beth and I are in disagreement about the things we say,” says Gail. “Simple things like I’ll say ‘plaster’ and she’ll say ‘Band-aid,’ I’ll say ‘chips’ and she’ll say ‘fries’. He knows that he’s betwixt and between terms.
“Even things like ‘wee’ and ‘what’s the craic?’ There are phrases I would say that, in the mouth of someone who’s not from here, they sound ridiculous. You can hear people, and English speakers in particular, trying to accommodate themselves, ‘Well, hello, what’s the craic?’ Or even words like ‘scundered’ or ‘jammy,’ or ‘dead on,’ all these things that I say quite often.”"
